This research focused on the hydrothermal tolerance of Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts. Either low- or high-temperature aging decreases the catalytic property of Cu/SAPO-34. Cu/SAPO-34 lost some isolated copper sites, and new copper-aluminum complexes CuAl2O4 and Al-rich CuO x clusters formed after low temperature aging. High temperature aging resulted in CuO x clusters and AlPO4 species formed, which led to the loss of Cu2+ active sites and surface nitrates adsorbed sites over Cu/SAPO-34. Cu/SSZ-13 retained the catalytic performance after low temperature aging but was totally intolerant to high temperature aging. High temperature hydrothermal aging led to the loss of active sites, lack of surface nitrates adsorbed sites, and serious structural degradation over Cu/SSZ-13. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu/CHA Structure-performance relationship Hydrothermal stability Physicochemical property Mechanism 1 Introduction The release of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) from diesel vehicles has contributed to numerous environmental issues and harmful effects on human lives. Although diesel engine has low CO2 output and high fuel efficiency [1-4], the serious NO x emissions have been strictly limited by emissions regulations, thus affecting the further development. There are several aftertreatment methods in exhaust tailpipes to solve the NO x emission problem. Selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) has been proven to be an appropriate and powerful NO x removal technique [5]. The V-based (WO3/MoO3-V2O5-TiO2) catalysts have been widely used as commercial products for the removal of NO x produced from stationary sources since the 1970s [6]. While V-based catalysts are highly resistant to sulfur poisoning, they still suffered several weaknesses when facing progressively stringent regulations on emissions. Metal-based (especially Cu or Fe) zeolite catalysts have instead attracted extensive interest, and have been researched and developed for several years. In a large temperature window, copper-based zeolite catalysts exhibit higher NO x conversion efficiency, promising selectivity, and environmentally friendly composition. Among these factors, broad attention was given to microporous molecular sieves with the chabazite (CHA) structure, such as Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13. Cu/SAPO-34 is recognized for excellent high temperature hydrothermal stability and lower N2O production compared to Cu/SSZ-13 [7, 8]. Nevertheless, Cu/SAPO-34 is found to have the problem of poor stability after low temperature hydrothermal aging, thus it is abandoned over the diesel vehicles on the market [9]. Frequent vehicle starting conditions accelerate the destruction of low temperature water molecules to Cu/SAPO-34 skeleton structure. Leistner et al. treated Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts at 70 °C for 9 h, and a 90 % conversion decrease was observed at around 200 °C over-aged sample [10]. Olsson et al. concluded that only 5% H2O at low temperature was enough to destroy the Cu/SAPO-34 structure and limit the SCR activity [11]. Wang et al. demonstrated that Cu/SAPO-34 aged at 70 °C showed a serious decline in catalytic performance [12, 13]. Cu/SSZ-13, as the most widely used SCR molecular sieve catalyst, also has a wide temperature window, excellent low temperature activity, and high selectivity. However, the high temperature hydrothermal stability is worse than Cu/SAPO-34 [14, 15]. Ma et al. demonstrated that Cu/SSZ-13 aged after 16 h at 850 °C showed significantly worse catalytic property than Cu/SAPO-34 treated at the same condition [16]. SCR catalysts must face a big challenge as pollution regulations become more stringent. To collect particulate matter (PM), diesel particulate filters (DPF) must be used, and regularly regenerate PM is carried out in order to maintain normal pressure drops. The regeneration induces periodic exposure of downstream SCR catalysts to humid gas flow at high temperatures. The extreme hydrothermal flow leads to zeolite skeleton collapse. Hence, one main feature of superior SCR zeolite catalysts high temperature hydrothermal stability. There are many studies about the low or high hydrothermal stability of Cu/CHA catalysts. Xiao et al. proposed that H2O at low temperature was prone to affect the framework of Cu/SAPO-34 with a high Si component [12]. The results of Wang et al. showed that the main deactivation of Cu/SAPO-34 at low temperature was the breakage of Si-O-Al sites [17]. Recently, Gao et al. concluded that the interaction of Cu(OH)2 and terminal Al species caused by low temperature hydrothermal aging was the main reason for the deactivation [9]. SCR active sites on Cu/SSZ-13 was Cu2+ sites, and high temperature hydrothermal aging led to the accumulation of copper sites to form CuO x cluster, resulting in the loss of activity and the destruction of zeolite structure [18]. Song et al. explored the high temperature hydrothermal stability of different active sites on Cu/SSZ-13, and found that copper site with two frameworks Al (Z2Cu sites) was more stable than the copper site with one framework Al (ZCuOH site) [19]. Our group had explored the hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 with various Si/Al [20], and also conclude the difference of high temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts prepared via the ion-exchange method and in situ hydrothermal method [21]. Although there are various studies about the low temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu/SAPO-34 and high temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu/SSZ-13, barely no literature investigating the comparison of the two Cu/CHA catalysts at the same hydrothermal condition. Exploring both low and high temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 is beneficial for revealing the instinct characteristic of hydrothermal stability and catalytic property. As two catalysts with similar CHA structures, their performance was different under the same deactivation conditions, which was worth exploring the reasons. A detailed understanding of the hydrothermal aging of Cu-CHA type molecular sieve catalysts at different temperature ranges is helpful to solve the existing problems of low temperature dealumination of SAPO-34 and poor high temperature stability of SSZ-13. These studies could play the role of theoretical guidance and data support for the further development of high durability SCR catalysts. In this research, fresh Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 were prepared through in situ hydrothermal syntheses. NH3 temperature programmed oxidation (NH3-TPO), NO temperature programmed oxidation (NO-TPO), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) were carried out to explore the oxidation capacity, active sites, and acidity. The samples were also characterized by BET, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) to detect physical properties and surface element distribution. NH3-SCR kinetic studies and in situ DRIFTS were carried out to further explore the influence of hydrothermal aging. Instinct characteristic of the catalytic property and hydrothermal stability over Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 were prepared through in situ hydrothermal method. The templates of Cu/SAPO-34 were copper-based tetraethylenepentamine (Cu-TEPA) and propylamine (PA). The initial proportion of reactants used in synthesis was 0.5 Al2O3: 1.0 H3PO4: 0.25 SiO2: 0.06 Cu-TEPA: 1.4 PA: 35 H2O. The initial gel was evenly mixed, then it was sealed in the Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. After the crystallization process for 72 h at 180 °C, the product was filtered using deionized water and dried for 12 h. The Cu/SAPO-34 was eventually obtained after the calcination at 700 °C for 5 h. The fresh Cu/SAPO-34 was labelled as SAPO-FS. The template of Cu/SSZ-13 was copper-based tetraethylenepentamine (Cu-TEPA). The initial proportion of reactants used in synthesis was 3.0 Al2O3: 15 Na2O: 600 H2O: 30 SiO2: 4 Cu-TEPA. The initial gel was evenly mixed, then it was sealed in the Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. After the crystallization process for 96 h at 140 °C, the product was filtered using deionized water and dried for 12 h. An ion exchange process with dilute HNO3 solution was added to remove excess copper in the sample. The Cu/SSZ-13 was eventually obtained after the calcination at 600 °C for 6 h. The fresh Cu/SSZ-13 was labelled as SSZ-FS. The condition of low temperature hydrothermal aging was at the air flow with 10 % vapor at 70 °C for 16 h. Then the sample was treated in air flow at 300 °C for 2 h, and the aged samples were named SAPO-LT and SSZ-LT. The condition of high temperature hydrothermal aging was at the air flow with 10 % vapor at 800 °C for 16 h. And the aged samples were named SAPO-HT and SSZ-HT. 2.2 Catalyst characterization H2-TPR was carried out on the Micromeritics Chemisorb 2720 equipment. 30 mg catalyst sample was placed in the U-shaped tube. A heating furnace was used as a temperature controller. About 35 ml/min H2 gas flowed through the tube. And the TCD signal was recorded by the thermal conductivity detector. The reducibility performance of catalysts was recorded from 100 °C to 600 °C. NH3-TPD was carried out on the Thermo NICOLET 6700. 40-60 mesh catalyst sample was placed in the microreactor. A heating furnace was used as a temperature controller. The sample was treated in a gas feed of 500 ppm NH3/N2 at a flow rate of 200 ml/min until saturation at 150 °C, then purged with N2 at the same temperature for 2 h. Finally, NH3 desorption took place at a ramp of 10 °C/min to 550 °C in a N2 flow of 200 ml/min. BET was carried out on Quantachrome NOVA 2000e. Catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C for 2 h. The adsorption-desorption isotherm of the catalyst was measured by the N2 low temperature physical adsorption method at the liquid nitrogen temperature (-196 °C) with the specific surface area analyzer. According to the measured curve, the BET specific surface area of the catalyst was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The total desorption pore volume, average pore size and pore size distribution of the catalyst were calculated by the BJH method. Powder X-ray Diffraction (XRD, D8 ADVANCE Da Vinci) was used to test the textural properties using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). XRD data were collected from 5° to 40°, and the acquisition time is 1.5 s. SEM images were acquired using field emission scanning electron microscope (HITACHI S-4800, HITACHI). The accelerating voltage is 10 kV. Samples were dried and sprayed with gold on the surface prior to SEM experiments. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on AXIS Ultra DLD (Shimadzu Kratos Ltd., JPN). Mg Kα radiation source was used. Prior to the analysis, the powder was heated at 100 °C for 2 h. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) of the fresh and aged catalysts was recorded at 153 K (EMX-8, Bruker). 2.3 Catalytic performance studies NH3-SCR catalytic activity and selectivity were performed in the microreactor. Prepared samples were treated to 40-60 mesh for the catalytic test. Catalysts were pretreated in air flow at 600 °C for 1 h. Then inlet gas flow was changed to standard SCR condition, which was 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 5 % O2, and balanced by N2. The total flow rate was 500 mL/min, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 400,000 h−1. The test points were in the 100-500 °C region. The products of NH3-SCR test reaction, such as NO, NO2, N2O, and NH3, were recorded by FT-IR (Thermo NICOLET 6700). The catalytic activity and selectivity were analyzed as follows: (1) N O x conversion = [ N O x ] in − [ N O x ] out [ N O x ] in × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity = [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N O 2 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in × 100 % (3) N 2 O selectivity = 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in × 100 % NH3-TPO was also conducted in the microreactor. Prepared samples were treated to 40-60 mesh for the catalytic test. Catalysts were pretreated in air flow at 600 °C for 1 h. Then inlet gas flow was changed to NH3-TPO condition, which was 500 ppm NH3, 5 % O2, and balanced by N2. The total flow rate was 500 mL/min, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 400,000 h−1. The test points were in the 100-500 °C region. The products were also recorded by FT-IR. NH3 conversion was calculated as follows: (4) N H 3 conversion = [ N H 3 ] in − [ N H 3 ] out [ N H 3 ] in × 100 % NO-TPO was also conducted in the microreactor. Prepared samples were treated to 40-60 mesh for the catalytic test. Catalysts were pretreated in air flow at 600 °C for 1 h. Then inlet gas flow was changed to NO-TPO condition, which was 500 ppm NO, 5 % O2, and balanced by N2. The total flow rate was 500 mL/min, and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 400,000 h−1. The test points were in the 100-500 °C region. The products were also recorded by FT-IR. NO conversion was calculated as follows: (5) NO conversion = [ N O ] in − [ N O ] out [ N O ] in × 100 % The test conditions of the chemical reaction kinetics were the same as the NH3-SCR performance test. The normalized reaction rate (r) was calculated using the first-order kinetic equation: (6) r = − F W × ln ( 1 − x ) W was the weight of the catalyst, x represents the NO conversion, and F was the NO flow rate. We use Arrhenius equation to calculate the activation energies and pre-exponential factors: (7) k = r [ N O ] 0 = A e ( − E a / R T ) 2.4 In situ DRIFTS Studies In situ DRIFTS data were obtained on Thermo NICOLET 6700, with Praying Mantis DRIFTS cell and the MCT detector. Catalyst powder was pretreated to remove the impurity before the test. NH3 and NO adsorption data at 50 °C were acquired after samples saturated with NH3 or NO. All spectra were recorded in the range of 4,000-400cm−1 by accumulating 64 scans, and the resolution was 4 cm−1. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization H2-TPR technique is an effective analysis test for elucidating the reducibility capacity of the catalyst and the valence state of active species. SAPO-type and SSZ-type samples were tested, and the H2-TPR results were displayed in Fig. 1 . According to previous studies, Cu/SSZ-13 showed three peaks below 400 °C, which were assigned as reduction of CuO, ZCuOH sites in CHA cages, and Z2Cu sites near D6R, respectively [22]. It had been proven that the reduction temperature of ZCuOH sites was lower than that of Z2Cu sites [23]. There were also various researches about the different reduction temperatures of CuO species [24-27]. Ma et al. discovered that CuO x nanoparticles, which were widely scattered, were also resistant to reduction and much simpler to reduce than other isolated Cu2+ ions. Thus at below 200 °C, nanosized CuO x particles can contribute to the first appeared peak [16]. Leistner et al. observed that Cu2+ species converted into inactive copper species after low temperature hydrothermal aging that could not be identified by H2-TPR [28]. It was further proposed by Wang et al. that these inactive copper species are CuAl2O4 [29]. It was fair to deduce that CuAl2O4 evolved during the aging process rather than CuO, and that the development of CuAl2O4 after low-temperature hydrothermal aging was the key cause of the de-activation of Cu/SAPO-34 [28]. Other research teams believed that such copper-aluminum composites could be attributed to CuAl2O4 species highly disordered, or Al-rich CuO x clusters [30, 31]. As shown from Fig. 1(a), there were two obvious peaks below 300 °C. Given that the first peak existed in all three SAPO-type catalysts, the reduction of Cu2+ sites to Cu+ could occur at about 170 °C, which represented ZCuOH sites. The second peak was only obvious in SAPO-FS, while the intensity became lower in SAPO-LT and almost disappeared in SAPO-HT. According to the previous results, the peak at 210 °C could be described as highly dispersed CuO species, which was also verified in the XRD section. The wide temperature range of H2 consumption appeared around 245 °C, which represented the reduction peak of the Z2Cu site, however, it was not obvious in the aged samples, which might be caused by the destruction of such sites or the overlap of different reduction peaks. The peak near 425 °C over SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT was attributed to the reduction of Cu+ to Cu0. We found the reduction temperature of the same type of isolated copper ions on the SAPO-FS catalyst was significantly lower than that of the aged catalysts, which indicated that aging treatment reduced the reducibility of the catalyst and affected its activity. It should be noted that the aged catalysts had new reduction peaks formed at around 255 °C and 350 °C. It can be inferred that the new peak was the copper contained compounds produced by hydrothermal aging. On SAPO-LT, there was the only high intensity of new peak at low temperature, while SAPO-HT contained both new peaks, and the intensity of high temperature peak was higher. Based on our experimental results, we inferred that low temperature hydrothermal aging resulted in much copper-aluminum complexes CuAlO x formed, and high temperature hydrothermal aging mainly transformed highly dispersed copper oxide species or nanosized CuO into the aggregated CuO x clusters. Furthermore, the total amount of reductive species on SAPO-LT decreased significantly, which also proved that CuAl2O4 species had poor reducibility, while Al-rich CuO x clusters were easy to be reduced by H2 at 255 °C. While the structures of the two catalysts are identical, there are variations in the processes of their elemental composition and preparation method, which may result in differences in their reducibility. SSZ-FS displayed a board peak from 100 °C to 400 °C which demonstrated copper sites were more closely related to the framework of zeolite, resulting in lower reducibility than SAPO-type. No apparent peaks were observed between 400 °C to 600 °C, which exhibited the reduction of Cu+ to Cu0 occurred at higher temperatures, and other researchers had also reached the same conclusion [32]. SSZ-LT had higher ZCuOH sites than SSZ-FS, which will be explained in the following sections. SSZ-HT showed barely any peaks below 200 °C, while two new peaks formed at 285 °C and 350 °C, respectively. According to the previous analysis, the former was derived from the reduction of CuAlO x species, and the latter was attributed to the aggregated CuO x clusters. Fig. 2 displayed the NH3-TPD data, and established the comparison of NH3 storage capacity over all the fresh and aged catalysts. It has been proved that three main acid sites can be detected by NH3-TPD technique, which are weak Lewis acid sites, strong Lewis acid sites related to isolated copper ions, and Brønsted acid sites, respectively [33]. Zhou et al. reported that there were also acid sites generated from extra-framework Al sites [34]. While Sommer found a new acid site may originate from the silanol group [35]. In a word, at low temperatures, the adsorption sites mainly refer to physisorbed NH3, isolated Cu ions Lewis acid sites, Cu-OH, and Si-OH. At high temperatures, ammonia mainly adsorbed on Al-OH and Al-OH-Si sites [36]. According to literature [37, 38], partial low temperature peaks can be due to the NH3 adsorbed at NH4 +, which is bound to Brønsted acid sites and is compatible with the conclusion by Borfecchia et al. that during NH3 adsorption, NH4 +•nNH3 (n≥1) was formed, and the decomposition of these complexes led to the peak of low-temperature desorption. However, the low temperature signal is often assumed to be weak acid sites created by extra-framework Al or terminal Al moieties. Moreover, Xu concluded that CuO x had the strong ability to adsorb NH3 as the medium-strong acid site [39]. As seen from Fig. 2(a), SAPO-FS had stronger NH3 storage capacity than the aged samples, demonstrating that either low or high hydrothermal aging destroyed the zeolite framework to reduce the active copper sites and Brønsted acid sites. SAPO-HT had a higher NH3 desorption concentration at temperatures above 300 °C than SAPO-LT. That might be due to the formation of more extra-framework Al and CuO x clusters, which had medium or strong acidity. According to the results of NH3-TPD over SSZ-type samples, low temperature hydrothermal aging can facilitate the formation of more acid sites. The higher NH3 storage capacity below 350 °C might be due to the more isolated Cu2+ formed, which was attributed to ZCuOH sites according to H2-TPR results. The NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites over SSZ-LT had a higher desorption temperature compared to SSZ-FS, and that was a benefit for high temperature NH3-SCR reaction, since the NH3 was more closely related to the framework of SSZ skeleton even at elevated temperatures. In addition, more Brønsted acid sites formed over the SSZ-LT sample, and that will be explained in the XRD section. SSZ-HT exhibited extremely low NH3 storage capacity, indicating that active sites and skeleton structures were seriously damaged through high temperature hydrothermal aging process. Table 1 showed the quantification of NH3 desorption amount for SAPO-type and SSZ-type samples before and after hydrothermal aging treatment. In order to investigate the physical properties and crystal structure of the catalyst, and to further outline the influence of hydrothermal aging, we have carried out a BET test. Table 2 listed BET surface area, total pore volume, and average pore radius of each sample. Compared to the two in situ hydrothermal synthesis prepared Cu/CHA zeolites, SSZ-type catalyst had a higher BET surface area and higher pore volume than SAPO-type catalyst, while they had a comparable average pore radius. Such difference referred to the various phases of synthesis, the conditions of crystallization, and the distinct after-treatment process. SAPO-LT decreased 19.9 % BET surface area and 20.1 % total pore volume compared to SAPO-FS. Indeed, the crystal structure of SAPO-LT had changed, and the partial CHA skeleton had been lost. Previous analysis in this study also revealed that low temperature hydrothermal aging resulted in the formation of some copper aluminum oxide species, which means that the Al in the framework was removed from the original position. High temperature hydrothermal aging had more severe over SAPO-type and led to an 82.0 % decrease of BET surface area and 81.3 % reduction of the total pore volume. As for SSZ-type samples, SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT had almost similar characteristic parameters, and that indicated low temperature hydrothermal aging had no obvious negative effect on specific surface area and pore volume of SSZ-type catalyst. SSZ-HT exhibited a 98.9 % decrease in BET surface area and a 98.3 % decrease in total pore volume, in addition, the average pore radius increased 61.1 % compared to SSZ-FS. The effect of high temperature hydrothermal aging on the SSZ-type catalyst was lethal, resulting in the loss of most physical structure characteristics. Fig. 3 displayed N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of each catalyst. According to the BDDT classification, there are six typical isotherms, which reflect the different types of material. Type Ⅰ isotherms with a plat line and sharp uptake refer to microporous materials. Type Ⅱ isotherms show uptake at high P/P0, and refer to microporous materials. Type Ⅳ isotherms with a significant hysteresis loop are assigned as mesoporous materials. SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT both showed typical Type Ⅰ isotherms, which is characteristic of microporous materials. However, SAPO-HT had a significant hysteresis loop, indicating that mesoporous structure formed. Like SAPO-type samples, SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT both showed microporous structures. Nevertheless, the absence of hysteresis loop over SSZ-HT stood for the formation of macroporous materials. In conclusion, high temperature hydrothermal aging had great damage to the structure of SSZ-type catalysts. XRD experiments were carried out to explore the textural properties of each sample, and the results were shown in Fig. 4 . The typical CHA framework characteristic diffraction peaks were at 9.5°, 14.0°, 16.1°, 17.8°, 20.7°, 25.0°, and 30.7° (PDF 34-0137), which was suitable for both SAPO-type and SSZ-type samples [40]. CuO phase (PDF 48-1548) was the key species to analyze the effect of hydrothermal aging, and its peaks were at 35.5° and 38.7°. SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT showed significant CHA structure, however, there were differences in their crystallinity. The concept of relative crystallinity is often used to compare the structural differences of similar substances [33]. The ratio of the total intensity of peaks at 9.5°, 20.7°, and 30.7° of the aged and fresh samples was defined as relative crystallinity [41, 42]. The relative crystallinity of SAPO-LT was 73.8 % due to the low temperature aging. Although CuO species existed in SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT according to H2-TPR results, no CuO phase peaks were observed. The absence was due to that small particles or nanosized CuO species were so highly dispersed that the XRD technique cannot detect the substance. There was a new peak at 21.5°, which was referred to AlPO4 phase (PDF 31-0028) [43]. This was caused by the peeling off SAPO-type skeleton, resulting from high temperature hydrothermal aging. In addition, peaks of CuO phase appeared, indicating that dispersed CuO species aggregated to form CuO x clusters, consistent with the H2-TPR results. As shown in Fig. 4(b), SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT both displayed obviously CHA structures without CuO phase peaks. SSZ-LT had 103.7 % relative crystallinity, which was the better crystallinity phase than the fresh catalyst. In the NH3-TPD section, SSZ-LT had more Brønsted acid sites than SSZ-FS, which might be due to the higher crystallinity leading to a more complete skeleton structure and active sites. SSZ-HT showed an amorphous phase with the board flat peak, resulting from high temperature hydrothermal aging. SEM experiments were carried out to detect the difference in the morphology and particle size of each sample, and the SEM results were shown in Fig. 5 . SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT exhibited the cubic morphology accompanied by small particles with irregular shapes. The difference was that the regular cubic particles in SAPO-LT were not dominant, and more irregular substances were produced. Although low temperature hygrothermal aging led to the formation of irregular fragmentary particles, the cubic material was not badly damaged. Nevertheless, the cubic particles of SAPO-HT had been destroyed and converted into irregularly shaped substances, resulting in the accumulation of particles. SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT had nearly spherical particles, which was also seen in other researches [21, 44]. Low temperature hydrothermal aging seems to reduce the particle size of SSZ-LT, which was also observed over the SAPO-type catalyst. SSZ-HT demonstrated a very significant aggregation phenomenon, and the particle size had evidently been expanded, forming different morphology. This suggested that high temperature hydrothermal aging could significantly alter the physicochemical properties of the SSZ-type catalysts, which was more extreme than the destruction of the SAPO-type catalysts. In the mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction, the copper sites play a significant role. Fig. 6 displayed the Cu 2p3/2 peaks for the samples. There are three couples of peaks from 930 to 965 eV. Three peaks with higher binding energies were assigned to Cu 2p1/2 peaks, and other low binding energy peaks corresponded to Cu 2p3/2 peaks [45]. The binding energies (BEs) at about 932.8 eV and 952.8 eV were attributed to CuO species on the surface. Peak pairs at around 953.2 eV and 955.9 eV represented isolated Cu2+ sites, which were in the form of Cu-O-Si-O species. Moreover, peaks at nearly 943.2 eV and 963.0 eV were the characteristic peaks of divalent copper, which were also called shake-up satellite peaks [46]. The CuO and Cu2+ peaks composed the main peak, which facilitated exploring the nature of the copper species. The ratio of the intensity of shake-up peaks (IS) to intensity of main peak (IM) was calculated as a crucial assessment criterion. According to the literature [43, 47], a higher IS/IM value means an increased Cu-O bond, indicating that the surface copper ion aggregation or the migration of surface copper species into the CHA framework. Table 3 showed the surface chemical composition and some key parameters calculated from XPS results. As shown from Fig. 6, surface Cu2+ species over SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT nearly had the same proportion. H2-TPR results showed the loss of Cu2+ sites and the formation of Al-rich CuO x cluster over the SAPO-LT sample. The constant proportion of Cu2+ over the surface of SAPO-LT demonstrated that both Cu2+ active sites and surface CuO species could participate in the formation of Al-rich CuO x clusters or CuAl2O4 species. And the intensity of peaks remained compared to SAPO-FS, illustrating that a relatively complete structure had been retained. However, SAPO-HT had 50.6 % CuO species on the surface, higher than SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT. High temperature hydrothermal aging led to the increase of surface CuO species, and the decrease in XPS peak intensity also indicated the decline of copper species, which might be caused by the loss of key species and active sites after the structural collapse. IS/IM value is an indication of the strength of the connection between the copper species and the catalyst. Three SAPO-type samples had similar IS/IM values. Although both low and high temperature aging damaged the SAPO-type catalysts, Cu-O bond strength remained stable, indicating that there were still many stable copper species in the catalyst framework. For SSZ-type samples, surface Cu2+ and of IS/IM value of SSZ-LT were higher than those of SSZ-FS. A slight increase of IS/IM value was observed on SSZ-LT, and that promotion might result from the more isolated Cu2+ sites and higher crystallinity. The increase of IS/IM value might also demonstrate that newly formed copper sites come from surface CuO species. 60.8 % surface CuO was observed over SSZ-HT, illustrating that more copper species accumulated to form aggregated CuO x clusters. The significant decrease of IS/IM value also exhibited the unstable Cu-O bond, caused by the structure collapse. The O 1s spectra of catalysts were shown in Fig 7 . O 1s XPS spectra from 528 eV to 536 eV were fitted into three peaks. The low binding energies (BEs) signal at around 531.4 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen (Oβ), and the medium BEs signal at around 532.3 eV was assigned as surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα), moreover, the high BEs signal at 533.2 eV approximately was corresponded to surface oxygen of hydroxyl species (Oγ) [47]. The surface chemisorbed oxygen plays an important role in redox ability, and it can promote the oxidation reaction of NO to enhance the fast SCR rate. Compared to SAPO-FS, low hydrothermal aging led to lower surface chemisorbed oxygen, and more lattice oxygen formed. However, SAPO-HT showed more surface chemisorbed oxygen ratio than SAPO-LT. As the H2-TPR results shown, mainly inert CuAl2O4 species and many Al-rich CuOx cluster species formed over SAPO-LT, on the contrary, abundant aggregated CuOx cluster and some Al-rich CuOx cluster species formed over SAPO-HT. According to reasonable speculation, the inert CuAl2O4 species contributed to more lattice oxygen, which led to less surface chemisorbed oxygen on SAPO-LT. For SAPO-HT, more AlPO4 and CuO x clusters formed due to the severe structure collapse, and they belong to surface chemisorbed oxygen. These substances played no role in increasing the activity of the catalyst, but aggravated the non-selective oxidation of ammonia reductants. SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT had a similar Oα/Ototal ratio resulted from low temperature hydrothermal aging that had little effect on the surface oxygen of SSZ-type catalyst. Like SAPO-HT, SSZ-HT also had a high surface chemisorbed oxygen ratio due to a large number of CuO x clusters species on its surface. Table 3 lists surface chemical composition, surface Cu2+, IS/IM value, and Oα ratio of the prepared catalysts calculated from XPS results. Surface P ratio of SAPO-LT and SAPO-HT both increased, indicating that AlPO4 formed after hydrothermal aging and migrated to the surface of the zeolite. XRD technique only detected AlPO4 on SAPO-HT. Hence, the AlPO4 particles generated by low temperature hydrothermal aging were small and did not aggregate, indicating that the damage to the structure of SAPO-LT was slight. Surface copper of SAPO-LT and SAPO-HT also both decreased, demonstrating the loss of active sites. SSZ-HT had the lowest surface copper species, and that meant it was extremely affected by hydrothermal aging. The appearance of large amounts of aluminum oxides on the surface also supported this claim. The electronic paramagnet resonance (EPR) experiments were carried out to explore the Cu2+ species of each sample, and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . EPR spectroscopy has been widely used in the analysis of copper-based molecular sieve catalysts [1]. EPR results could further confirm the relative content of Cu2+ species. There is one unpaired electron on isolated Cu2+, which can be captured by an EPR signal. Isolated Cu2+ was the main active site in Cu/CHA catalysts, and the number of active sites influences the catalytic performance and the structure stability. CuO species and Cu+ species (such as isolated Cu+, [Cu-O]+, and [Cu-O-Cu]+) cannot be detected by the EPR technique [2,3]. As shown from Fig. 8, SAPO-LT had lower signal intensity than SAPO-FS, which indicated low temperature aging led to the loss of isolated copper sites, and the results were consistent with H2-TPR. High temperature aging caused more active sites lost, for aggregated CuO x clusters and Al-rich CuO x clusters formed. SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT had nearly the same signal intensity, which demonstrated that low temperature aging had little effect on the total isolated copper sites. However, high temperature aging resulted in a large loss of active sites in Cu/SSZ-13. 3.2 Catalytic performance The prepared Cu/CHA samples and hydrothermally treated catalysts were evaluated to explore the catalytic conversion efficiency of nitrogen oxides, and the results were plotted in Fig. 9 . The test range was between 100 °C and 500 °C, which covered most of the catalytic temperature conditions. As shown in Fig. 9(a), SAPO-FS exhibited high conversion over 80 % in a wide range from 175 °C to 450 °C. Whereas, both low and high temperature hydrothermal aging inhibited the catalytic activity of Cu/SAPO-34 sample. SAPO-LT and SAPO-HT both exhibited more inferior efficiency below 350 °C compared to the fresh samples. The temperature window of efficiency above 80% over SAPO-LT narrowed, which was only 200 °C to 400 °C, and that was 225 °C to 350 °C for SAPO-HT. A slightly higher conversion efficiency was observed over SAPO-LT above 350 °C, furthermore, SAPO-HT still demonstrated worse NO x removal efficiency than the fresh sample. As for the Cu/SSZ-13 sample, low temperature aging treatment appeared to have little effect on the catalytic efficiency, as displayed in Fig. 9(b). SSZ-FS presented over 85 % NO x removal efficiency from 175 °C to 500 °C. SSZ-LT still retained a catalytic performance close to that of the fresh catalyst. It is worth noting that SSZ-LT showed better conversion above 450 °C. However, high temperature hydrothermal aging had a fatal impact on Cu/SSZ-13 catalyst. In the entire temperature spectrum, SSZ-HT nearly lacked normal activity and showed less than 75% conversion, which was totally incapable of satisfying the catalytic requirements. Resistance to hydrothermal aging is an important evaluation index for SCR catalysts. Obviously, the hydrothermal stability of the two Cu/CHA catalysts presented a drastic difference. Low temperature hydrothermal aging displayed a distinct decline in activity over Cu/SAPO-34 at low temperatures, but a promising promoting effect at high temperatures. The Cu+ to Cu2+ reoxidation process is the rate-limiting stage of the low temperature SCR reaction cycle, which mainly refers to the single solvated [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+ sites to form [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+-O2- [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+ intermediate [48]. We hypothesized that the formation of solvated [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+ and the double copper dimer was limited. Hence, the efficiency reduction of SAPO-LT at low temperature range might be due to the degradation of reducibility and the limitation on the migration of active [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+ sites. In the high temperature range, the high conversion rate of SAPO-LT might also be due to the reduction of surface copper oxides, thereby reducing the non-selective oxidation of ammonia. Besides, ZCuOH sites in the CHA structure are more active than Z2Cu sites in the SCR reaction, resulting from that the reactants are less restricted in binging to ZCuOH sites [49]. According to reasonable speculation, ZCuOH sites might also play a role in the enhancement of high temperature activity. The active sites could retain in SSZ-LT according to the evenly matched NO x conversion. Apparently, high temperature hydrothermal aging damaged both catalysts SAPO-HT and SSZ-HT, which might be caused by the loss of active sites. Even worse, the decline of SSZ-HT was drastic, indicating serious structural changes had occurred. The selectivity of N2 and N2O were also evaluated, and the results were displayed in Fig. 10 . SAPO-HT showed lower N2 selective and higher N2O selective than SAPO-FS. The variation trend of selectivity of SAPO-LT varying with temperature was consistent with the change of conversion. Notably, no excess N2O formed over SAPO-LT compared to SAPO-FS. As shown in Fig. 10(b), there was not much difference in selectivity between SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT. However, SSZ-HT presented lower selectivity in the whole temperature range and higher N2O by-products above 225 °C. Notice that for all catalysts below 300 °C, there was an extreme value of N2O selectivity. As the temperature increased, the excess nitrate formed at low temperatures tended to decompose, releasing a significant volume of N2O [45]. N2O is an undesirable product in SCR reaction, and the formation curves are related to the change of reaction path over active sites. Despite more total N2O formed at high temperature aged samples, SSZ-HT produced less N2O below 200 °C, demonstrating that fewer reaction sites were left for SCR reaction. Ammonia oxidation is the side-pathway with detrimental results in the SCR reaction process, due to the competitive consumption of reducing agents and the formation of excess nitrogen oxides. The NH3 conversion results were plotted in Fig. 11 . According to the previous studies, Cu is necessary for the process of NH3 oxidation, because CHA zeolite without metal is not sensitive to the reaction [45]. Cu oxide was verified to promote the NH3 oxidation, and during the preparation of the copper-based molecular sieve, there would be residual copper oxides on the surface of the zeolite structure that have not been completely exchanged. At low temperatures, isolated copper sites were directly involved in the oxidation through NH3 solvated species Cu2+-NH3, moreover, copper-oxide species played a vital role in the whole temperature range. The widely accepted mechanism, which was represented by equations (8) and (9), to explain the NH3 oxidation has been used in extensive studies of copper-based catalysts supporting its validity [50, 51]. Ammonia is preferentially oxidized to nitrous oxide, which reacts with ammonia to form nitrogen and water. The NO reduction step mainly occurred over Cu2+-NH3 sites, and Brønsted acid sites will also be involved at elevated temperatures [52]. (8) 4 N H 3 + 5 O 2 → 4 NO + 6 H 2 O (9) 4 N H 3 + 4 NO + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O As shown in Fig. 11(a), SAPO-LT exhibited slightly higher NH3 conversion than SAPO-FS below 300 °C, but obviously lower conversion above 300 °C. As the ammonia oxidation efficiency showed a downward trend at most middle and elevated temperature points, it is speculated that the Cu oxides might increase. However, the conversion at 250 °C might be due to the formation of some oxidation sites, which will verify in our future experiments. Combining NH3-SCR and NH3-TPO analysis, the comparison of SAPO-FS and SAPO-LT results indicated that isolated Cu2+ sites and copper oxides species both decreased. That means the formation of a new copper-containing species, which was inert in ammonia oxidation. SAPO-HT showed higher NH3 conversion in the whole temperature range, demonstrating that more CuO x clusters formed over it. As for SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT samples, a conversion peak was observed at near 250 °C. The data from section 3.1 showed that the NH3-SCR conversion of both samples at 250 °C was 100%. The oxidation step was mainly controlled by copper oxides species, which remained on the catalyst surface, and Cu2+-NH3 sites also mattered. Furthermore, the reduction step exhibited a high rate, thereby weakened the rate limitation of the oxidation step, then strengthened the ability of ammonia oxidation. With the temperature increasing, the reduction step slowed down gradually, resulting in the decrease of NH3 conversion. This phenomenon was mainly due to the reaction mechanism of the reduction step in this temperature range. The “seagull-shape” curve was observed in other studies about the NO x conversion trend [53, 54], and the reduction step in NH3 oxidation reaction was related to the mechanism of the NH3-SCR reaction. The trend of non-monotonic growth of conversion is due to the difference in reaction mechanism caused by the changes of active sites in different temperature ranges. SSZ-LT showed higher NH3 oxidation conversion from 250 °C to 400 °C than SSZ-FS, indicating more active sites over the SSZ-LT sample. After that, the oxidation rate increased with the temperature. SSZ-HT did not follow that rule, and its conversion increased with the temperature in the whole test range, due to the decrease of sites for reduction steps. The concentration of NO x and N2O formed in the process of NH3 oxidation was displayed in Fig. 12 to verify the ability of the oxidation step and reduction step. As shown in Fig. 12(a), the majority of NO x formed after 400 °C, at which the NH3 conversion was close to or reached 100% conversion efficiency. The reduction step was balanced with the oxidation step, and that depended on the SCR catalytic ability. The non-selectively oxidation products NO x gases formed mean strong oxidation capacity of samples with much surface copper oxides species. Hence, SAPO-HT had more surface CuO x species and SAPO-LT had less than SAPO-LT. The N2O formation was consistent with the NO x produced, which was also a criterion for selective oxidation ability. Fig. 12(c) exhibited that much NO x was produced over three SSZ-type samples at 200 °C, corresponding to the temperature point where the ammonia conversion efficiency began to rise sharply. That might be due to the partial non-selectively reduction capacity at the reduction step, but the amount of NO x produced was small, except for SSZ-HT. In general, SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT retained low NO x and N2O formation in the whole temperature range. SSZ-HT exhibited strong non-selective oxidation due to its high content of surface copper oxides species and low amount of active sites. NO temperature programmed oxidation (NO-TPO) tests were carried out, and the results were shown in Fig. 13 . Most of the NO x is composed of NO in the exhaust gas, and the standard SCR has a relatively large contribution to the removal of the NO x compound. According to reports [55], the oxidation reaction of NO to NO2 occurred on transition metal-based molecular sieve catalysts, and many researchers had proposed that this reaction was one of the rate control steps in the standard SCR mechanism. Two types of NO oxidation sites were found, which were Type Ⅰ sites (N oxidation state +2 to +3) and Type Ⅱ sites (N oxidation state +2 to higher values), respectively [56]. As the presence of NO2 can contribute to the fast SCR reaction, it is also worth exploring the oxidation efficiency of NO. Bates et al. recorded that NO was almost impossible to oxidize at active sites near D6R [57]. Gao et al. found oxidation reactions with two degrees of energy activity in low and high temperature regions [58]. The oxidation efficiency of the ZCuOH site in the low temperature region is better than the Z2Cu site. NO oxidation reaction occurred over ZCuOH sites at low temperatures and at metal oxides species at high temperatures, according to fair speculation. As the conversion rate of NO was influenced by the chemical equilibrium of NO and NO2, the curve of NO conversion results showed an apparent volcanic form. As shown in Fig. 13, SAPO-FS and SSZ-FS both showed a relatively low NO conversion, which was agreed with other studies [59-61]. However, there was a wide conversion interval from 250 °C to 600 °C over SAPO-FS. Given that conversion of SAPO-HT had the same peak at 400 °C approximately, surface CuO x species existed in both SAPO-FS and SAPO-HT samples. As for SAPO-LT, NH3-TPO showed it had less CuO x remained, but more other copper-containing species formed. Such species might contribute to the NO conversion process according to the results, and that will further be explained in the in-situ DRIFTS section. SSZ-HT also had many CuO x species for the broad peak at 400 °C. Interestingly, a small peak at 250 °C occurred over SSZ-LT test results, indicating that isolated copper sites promoted the reaction at low temperatures. The same conversion trend at high temperature region of SSZ-FS and SSZ-LT implied that the content of copper oxides on the surface of these two catalysts was less, or not conducive to the oxidation of NO over SSZ-type zeolite. Notably, SSZ-HT started NO conversion at nearly 250 °C, while that was 200 °C or even less for SAPO-HT. The difference stood for less damage over SAPO-HT than SSZ-HT because there was still active sites reaction steps at low temperatures. In order to further explore the influence of low and high temperature hydrothermal aging on the two catalysts, we calculated the activation energy and pre-exponential factor from the data of NO x conversion. High GHSV during the NH3-SCR test was adopted, which ensured that the efficiency of the catalysts was not affected by the external diffusion effect [21]. As shown in Fig. 14 , SSZ-FS had a significantly higher pre-exponential factor compared to SAPO-FS. According to previous sections, the ratio of copper ions and chemisorbed oxygen on the SSZ-FS surface was higher, and the strength of the Cu-O bond was lower, which was conducive to accelerate the binding of reactants and copper sites, thus accelerating the reaction. SAPO-LT had a pre-exponential factor similar to SAPO-FS, indicating the physicochemical properties of most active sites were almost not affected, and the effect of low temperature hydrothermal aging on the active sites was limited. The pre-exponential factor of SAPO-HT was obviously lower than SAPO-FS, and the severe damage of high temperature hydrothermal aging reduced the catalytic transformation performance of the active sites. SSZ-LT had a higher reaction rate than SSZ-FS. According to H2-TPR results, more ZCuOH sites formed after low temperature hydrothermal aging, and ZCuOH sites were more active than Z2Cu sites in SCR reaction [19, 46]. Besides, XRD also showed that SSZ-LT had higher crystallinity leading to a more complete skeleton structure and active sites. SSZ-HT had an extremely low pre-exponential factor, which could be verified by the low NH3-SCR performance. The activation energy (Ea) of SAPO-FS was lower than that of SSZ-FS. Paolucci et al. concluded that the rate-limiting step of SCR reaction on Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst was that the single solvated [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+ sites to form [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+-O2- [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+ intermediate, which was controlled by the mobility and spatial density of copper ions [62]. Hence, these two different catalysts have a different spatial distribution of copper ions and the structure of the molecular sieve, which would lead to the difference of activation energy between them [63]. Low temperature hydrothermal aging led to a slight increase of Ea value, indicating that the reaction pathway had changed. High temperature hydrothermal aging obviously decreased the Ea value due to the loss of active sites, formation of CuO x clusters, and the skeleton collapse. 3.3 In situ DRIFTS The relationship between active sites distribution and catalytic performance of Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts after hydrothermal aging treatment was studied by in situ DRIFTS analysis using NH3 as the probe. NH3 adsorption can detect Cu2+ sites or Brønsted O-H bond, besides NH3 and OH groups can form NH4 + cations. The detected sites are distributed mainly in two vibrational regions. The N-H bending signal was at the high wavenumber region, which was 1375-1675 cm−1 for SAPO-type and 1400-1700 cm−1 for SSZ-type. The peaks at higher wavenumber were corresponded to Lewis acid sites with adsorbed NH3, and the lower wavenumber peaks were attributed to Brønsted acid sites with adsorbed NH4 + species. The T-O-T stretching vibrations signal was at the low wavenumber region, which was 800-950 cm−1 for SAPO-type and 850-1000 cm−1 for SSZ-type. T-O-T stretching vibration was caused by the introduction of Cu species in the zeolite framework [45]. The two negative peaks in this region represent the stretching vibrations of T-O-T caused by two different copper ions’ active sites, which were Z2Cu and ZCuOH, respectively. Since the wavenumber can also reflect the stability, the peak at the high wavenumber represents the ZCuOH sites, and the peak value at the low wavenumber is assigned as the Z2Cu site [46]. Fig. 15 exhibited the peak fitting results of NH3+O2 adsorption DRIFTS spectra. Fig. 16 displayed the peak intensity of NH3+O2 adsorption DRIFTS spectra. For SAPO-type catalysts, both low and high hydrothermal aging led to a loss of Brønsted acid sites, and the damage was even more severe over SAPO-HT. The most peak intensity of the ZCuOH site remained over SAPO-LT, and partial ZCuOH sites decreased over SAPO-HT, which also corresponded to the results of H2-TPR. Z2Cu sites were significantly reduced after aging, which also proved that the Z2Cu site in SAPO-type catalyst was more prone to deterioration than the ZCuOH site. It is worth noting that the Lewis acid sites had little change before and after aging, which might be due to that the copper oxide produced after aging could also adsorb NH3. As for SSZ-type catalysts, SSZ-LT had fewer Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites than SSZ-FS. However, SSZ-LT remained intact zeolite structure, and the lost acid sites mainly not referred to the copper sites or Si-O(H)-Al bonds. SSZ-LT had a stronger NH3 storage capacity at 150 °C according to NH3-TPD, however, in situ DRIFTS results showed a higher NH3 adsorption amount of SSZ-FS. Hence, we speculated that NH3 adsorbed on SSZ-LT was more stable, which was beneficial for NH3-SCR reaction. Moreover, the intensity of the stretching vibrations caused by Z2Cu sites decreased over low temperature hydrothermal aging, indicating that the copper sites bond weakly to the skeleton, which could promote the redox ability of SSZ-LT. High temperature hydrothermal aging significantly destroy the active sites, and led to little NH3 adsorbed sites left over SSZ-HT. NO+O2 adsorption in-situ DRIFTS were carried out to explore the surface nitrates adsorbed sites over Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts before and after hydrothermal aging treatment. The peak fitting results according to Gaussian deconvolution method were shown in Fig. 17 , and the intensity of each peak was plotted in Fig. 18 . The signals of four types of NO x adsorbed sites fall in the 1425-1725 cm−1 region. The typical sites were attributed to nitrites sites (1635-1667 cm−1), bridging nitrates sites (1610-1619 cm−1), bidentate nitrates sites (1561-1599 cm−1), and monodentate nitrates sites (1499-1518 cm−1), respectively [21, 46, 64]. Bidentate nitrates were fitted to doublet peaks α and β for facilitating data analysis and concluding the differences. SAPO-LT exhibited more nitrites and less monodentate nitrates adsorbed sites than SAPO-FS. According to results in the NO-TPO section, SAPO-LT was efficient at NO oxidation, which would lead to the formation of abundant nitrites intermediate species. However, the loss of monodentate nitrates affected the NH3-SCR reaction, because it was the key species in the redox cycle [21]. Hence, CuAl2O4 species, not copper ion sites, contributed to the NO conversion process over SAPO-LT. Though SAPO-HT had more monodentate nitrates adsorbed sites, loss of active sites and skeleton collaspes still led to the decrease of efficiency. As for SSZ-type catalysts, low temperature hydrothermal aging had no effect on the monodentate nitrates adsorbed sites, but significantly increased the nitrites sites, indicating that the more copper ion sites over SSZ-LT promoted the NO oxidation reaction to realize the “fast SCR”. SSZ-HT lost most surface nitrates adsorbed sites due to the severe hydrothermal aging damage. 3.4 Instinct characteristic of catalytic property and hydrothermal stability over Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 The instinct characteristic of the catalytic property and hydrothermal stability over Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 can be proposed according to our data results and analysis, and the schematic diagram was displayed in Fig. 19 . SAPO-LT had lower catalytic efficiency below 350 °C than SAPO-FS, which might be caused by the degradation of reducibility and limitation on the migration of active [CuⅠ(NH3)2]+ sites. The higher conversion above 350 °C might also be due to the reduction of non-selective oxidation of ammonia. Isolated copper sites and copper oxides both decreased after low temperature hydrothermal aging, and participated in the formation of surface CuAl2O4 and Al-rich CuO x clusters. Z2Cu site in SAPO-type catalyst was more prone to deterioration than ZCuOH site. SAPO-LT exhibited less surface chemisorbed oxygen and monodentate nitrates adsorbed sites than SAPO-FS. Although more irregular substances were produced, SAPO-LT remained microporous structure, retained 73.8% relative crystallinity, and only lost 19.9 % BET surface area. Partial Al-rich CuO x clusters and aggregated CuO x clusters formed over SAPO-HT, resulting in loss of Cu2+ active sites and surface nitrates adsorbed sites. High hydrothermal aging led to more extra-framework Al sites, aggregated AlPO4 species, and accumulated particles formed. Serious damage resulted in irregularly shaped substances and mesoporous over SAPO-HT. SSZ-LT still retained a catalytic performance close to that of the fresh catalyst. More ZCuOH sites formed after low temperature hydrothermal aging. Cu sites had lower Cu-O bond strength, which could promote the redox ability of SSZ-LT. Stronger NH3 adsorption capacity and more nitrites sites were observed, which were beneficial for NH3-SCR reaction. Besides, SSZ-LT had a higher relative crystallinity and smaller particle size, also contributing to the promising performance. SSZ-HT nearly lacked normal activity and showed less than 75% conversion. High temperature hydrothermal aging led to the loss of active sites, lack of surface nitrates adsorbed sites, and serious structural degradation. Abundant aggregated CuO x clusters and some Al-rich CuO x clusters covered the surface. SSZ-HT showed macroporous material characteristics, and the particle size had evidently been expanded, forming different morphology. 4 Conclusions The fresh Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts were prepared via in situ hydrothermal methods. Aged samples were prepared for exploring the hydrothermal stability. SAPO-FS exhibited high conversion over 80 % from 175 °C to 450 °C. SAPO-LT showed worse performance than SAPO-FS, but higher catalytic conversion than SAPO-HT. SSZ-FS displayed over 85 % NO x removal efficiency from 175 °C to 500 °C. SSZ-LT still retained the close catalytic performance, but SSZ-HT showed less than 75% conversion. NH3-TPO and NO-TPO explore the oxidation capacity of catalysts, and the results demonstrated that copper ions and CuOx species both decreased, followed by a new forming copper-containing species over SAPO-LT, which contributed to the NO conversion. H2-TPR and NH3-TPD investigated the active sites for each sample. The reducibility of SAPO-LT was weakened, and some isolated Cu2+ sites and surface CuO x species were lost, resulting in the formation of two new copper oxide species, CuAl2O4 species and Al-rich CuO x clusters. More extra-framework Al and CuO x clusters appeared over SAPO-HT, forming abundant aggregated CuO x clusters and a few Al-rich CuO x clusters. SSZ-LT exhibited more ZCuOH sites, and showed stable NH3 storage capacity. SSZ-HT formed plenty of CuAlO x species and aggregated CuO x clusters. The samples were also characterized by BET, XRD, SEM, and XPS. SAPO-LT showed more irregular substances, and there were still many stable copper species in the catalyst framework of SAPO-LT. SAPO-HT showed irregularly shaped large-sized substances, and exhibited mesoporous structure with AlPO4 species and aggregated CuO phase. SSZ-LT remained microporous structure and had a smaller particle size than the fresh sample. SSZ-HT showed macroporous structure and aggregated particles, resulting from the significant reduction in physical and chemical properties. Moreover, NH3-SCR kinetic studies and in situ DRIFTS were carried out to further explore the influence of hydrothermal aging. Z2Cu site in SAPO-type catalyst was more prone to deterioration than ZCuOH site. Though SAPO-HT had more monodentate nitrates adsorbed sites, loss of active sites and skeleton collapse still led to the decrease of efficiency. SSZ-LT showed a higher reaction rate than SSZ-FS for more ZCuOH sites forming. Copper sites bond weakly to the skeleton, which could promote the redox ability of SSZ-LT. SSZ-HT lost most surface NH3 adsorbed sites and nitrates adsorbed sites due to the severe hydrothermal aging damage. Instinct characteristic of the catalytic property and hydrothermal stability over Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 was also proposed. Credit author statements Han Jiang: Writing- Original draft preparation. coredata.dc:description: This research focused on the hydrothermal tolerance of Cu/SAPO-34 and Cu/SSZ-13 catalysts. Either low- or high-temperature aging decreases the catalytic property of Cu/SAPO-34. Cu/SAPO-34 lost some isolated copper sites, and new copper-aluminum complexes CuAl2O4 and Al-rich CuO x clusters formed after low temperature aging. High temperature aging resulted in CuO x clusters and AlPO4 species formed, which led to the loss of Cu2+ active sites and surface nitrates adsorbed sites over Cu/SAPO-34. Cu/SSZ-13 retained the catalytic performance after low temperature aging but was totally intolerant to high temperature aging. High temperature hydrothermal aging led to the loss of active sites, lack of surface nitrates adsorbed sites, and serious structural degradation over Cu/SSZ-13.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrothermal tolerance towards different temperature conditions over two typical Cu/CHA catalysts
